title: Does India need 2 timezones?

transcript: Take a look at this map. Russia has 11 time zones. France has 12, but our huge country only has one. And it costs us 29,000 crores every year. Let me explain. The sun rises in Mumbai at around 6:00 a.m. But in Gujhati, it's at 4:30 a.m. So by the time offices and schools open, peak daylight hours are already gone in the east. It leads to lower productivity and huge electricity consumption in the evenings because the sun sets early. title: 3 Star AC vs 5 Star AC- Which one should you get?‚ö°Ô∏è
transcript: A cheaper AC but higher electricity bill or an expensive AC and lower electricity bill. They say five-star AC saves 25% on your electricity bill, but that's only half the truth. Meaning you recover the extra cost in 3 years, 9 months. In Bangalore, it's 830 rupees per year, 11 plus years to break even. Not worth it. In Mumbai, with higher electricity rates, it's not that good. But here's the twist. title: Indian Railways have received a hefty electricity bill and it could increase your ticket prices!

title: Shocking Truth Behind Great Wall Of India!
transcript: This enemy is silently invading India. And to stop it, we are building the Great Wall. A tree-based wall that is 1,400 km long and 5 km wide stretching from Gujarat to Delhi, covering 14 districts. But why? The Thar Desert is slowly moving towards central India. In just 15 years, it's damaged over 3.46 cr acres of land. But the real enemy is not the desert. Earlier the Aravly Hills acted as a natural barrier and stopped thar dust and winds from moving east. Years of illegal mining and deforestation have broken that shield. By 2018, reports said 20% of the Arably Hills had already disappeared in the state of Rajasthan and the remaining hills are no longer able to stop dust storms, polluted air and dry soil from reaching north India. title: RBI Hikes Fee From May 1 | What It Means for You‚ö°

With UPI rising, banks are shutting down ATMs and pushing digital because it's cheaper. Back in 2023, ATM usage was already falling. The average person used an ATM just eight times a year, down from 16 visits in 2022, and it's been declining ever since, making ATMs nearly obsolete. But who pays the price? title: No cost EMI is a SCAM!!‚ö°
transcript: Everyone's talking about no cost EMI like it's free money, but no one's talking about this sneaky trick that's making you buy now, cry later. Did you know in the great Indian festival sale, three out of four products were sold via no cost EMI? Sounds like a deal, right? But banks actually can't legally give interestf free loans. So what really happens? The product costs 79,900 rupees, but the bank charges 15% interest. That's 13,78 rupees which will be covered by Apple. But you still pay 18% GST on the interest 2,354 rupees. On top of that, there's a onetime processing fee of 199 rupees plus 36 rupees GST. So now your total cost is 82,489 rupees over 24 months, which simply means you're effectively paying more. And if you try to close the EMI early, guess what? You'll have to pay for closure charges. So no, you didn't get a zero interest loan. You got gamified debt wrapped in pretty packaging.

transcript: This one Belgian biscuit completely hijacked India's dessert menu. It started way back in 1932 in a Belgian bakery named Lotus. But the real marketing genius happened in the 80s on an airplane. [music] Delta Airlines handed out millions of these biscuits for free. If you traveled, you ate biskoff. It quickly became a flyer status symbol. That premium reputation landed in western cafes and eventually exploded on India's Instagram feeds. [music] But for years it remained a pricey imported luxury. Then 2024 changed everything. Lotus partnered with Mondilus and by 2025 it started local manufacturing.

Doms is skipping that step. They're acquiring the actual manufacturers. By owning the factory, they stop paying the middleman's profit. They keep that money and use it to lower prices. title: DUBAI'S Gold Is PURER Than INDIAN Gold? REALLY? ü§Ø
transcript: Wait, does Dubai actually have better quality gold compared to India? Let's check. While gold jewelry from Dubai looks more yellowish, Indian gold often has a slightly copper reddish tone. That's because when gold is made into jewelry, it is not 100% pure gold. To make it sturdy and durable, an alloy is added to the gold. So, in 22 karat gold, out of 1,000 g, 916 g is pure gold and the remaining 84 g is an alloy. Now the composition of this alloy decides the color of the jewelry. If the alloy contains a high percentage of silver or zinc, the gold appears more yellow. But if the alloy has more copper, the jewelry takes on a reddish or copper tone.

title: If MRP didn‚Äôt exist!‚ö°
transcript: Imagine walking into a shop to buy Lays or Maggie and bargaining for it. Sounds weird, right? Well, this was a reality before 1990. Back then, India had no fixed prices. Retailers could charge whatever they liked. Price literally depended on where you lived, how you looked or how desperate you were. And this created chaos. Consumers were being overcharged. So, in 1990, the government stepped in. They introduced MRP, maximum retail price. To protect consumers from exploitation, every product now had to carry a printed price. the ceiling no one could cross. MRP isn't the price, it's the maximum price. Retailers are legally allowed to sell below it. But do they? India is one of the few countries in the world to enforce MRP. Most developed countries like the US, UK and most of Europe allow open pricing.

title: MUMBAI's forgotten gem GILBERT HILL‚õ∞Ô∏è
transcript: In Mumbai's Anhiri, there exists a hill that is older than the human race. Located just 10 minutes away from Andhiri station, Gilbert Hill was formed around 65 million years ago. It was created due to volcanic activity during which Vasal rocks fell at three different places on Earth. Out of these, two rocks formed similar hills in the United States while one fell in India. Now, a hill this rare would obviously be very well preserved. However, the 225 ft tall Gilbert Hill, which until 60 to 70 years ago was surrounded by vegetation, today stands trapped between multi-story buildings and slums. Because of this, now the hill is slowly eroding.

title: Britain's 100 Year Bamboo Blunder üå≥
transcript: This one British law almost killed India's bamboo industry. India sits on the second largest bamboo reserves on the [music] planet. Yet we still import most of our bamboo from China. The root cause goes back to 1927. [music] The Indian Forest Act labeled bamboo a tree. Cutting it on your own land needed permits. Violating that [music] could even mean a criminal case. So farmers did the logical thing. They simply stopped planting bamboo. But in 2017, the law changed. [music] Bamboo was reclassified as grass. Farmers could finally cut and sell it without forest [music] permits.

title: What's cheaper? EV or Petrol cars?‚ö°
transcript: Thinking EVs are cheaper. Let's break it down. EVs cost just 1.5 rupees per kmter versus 8 rupees for petrol and maintenance is comparatively cheaper. Sounds great, right? But here's the hidden cost. Battery replacement is 3 to 4.5 lak rupees. And in some EVs, even 7 to 12 lak rupees. And depreciation. EVs generally depreciate more than fuel cars. Meanwhile, fuel cars hold value better because they have proven long-term reliability. Speaking of charging, fast charges degrade batteries faster and home charging takes 8 plus hours. Not to mention, India still has limited charging infrastructure compared to fuel stations. So, EV or fuel, both have pros and cons. If you drive a lot and have access to home charging, an EV might make sense, but if you want long-term reliability and resale value, a fuel car still holds strong. The smartest choice, the one that fits your lifestyle, not just the trend.

title: India's Gold Demand Is Bigger Than You Think!ü™ô
Get a PROPERTY for FREE
description:
üö® No EMI till possession üö® - this promise sounds too good to be true, isn't it? 

And for thousands of homebuyers, this promise to them turned into a nightmare.

Here‚Äôs what might happen in these subvention schemes: You book an under-construction flat, take a home loan, and the builder promises to pay your EMIs till the flat is ready. So you think, ‚ÄúPerfect! I‚Äôll just pay 10-20% now and won‚Äôt have to worry about EMIs for a while.‚Äù

But the problem starts when the builder delays the project or stops paying EMIs. Since the loan is in your name, the bank comes after you. Your credit score takes a hit. And you are stuck paying both rent and EMI. And worst of all, the flat is still half built and is far from completion. 

This trick became popular after 2010 and was used heavily till 2019. Even though RBI and NHB warned banks, and RERA rules said money should be released to builders only as construction progresses, many builders still found ways around it - especially in smaller cities.

Recently, the Supreme Court said RERA should not be a ‚Äútoothless tiger‚Äù and that homebuyers deserve stronger protection.

In a nutshell, if someone offers you a deal that sounds too easy - think twice :) 

Ask questions. Check if the loan is linked to construction progress. And remember, in finance, there‚Äôs no such thing as a free lunch.

Explore more about this topic here: 

1. Newsletter by Zerodha Varsity: https://zerodhavarsity.substack.com/p/homebuyers-dont-fall-for-subvention

2. Notification by RBI: https://rbi.org.in/scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=8366&Mode=0

3. Supreme Court's judgement: https://api.sci.gov.in/supremecourt/2020/25752/25752_2020_8_1506_64231_Judgement_12-Sep-2025.pdf
transcript: This deal is amazing. No EMI till possession. Basically, you get a home and the builder pays your EMIs until your house is ready. This could be a scam because after the 2008 subprime crash, banks stopped lending to builders. So, builders started asking home buyers to take the loan instead, and the builder promises to pay the EMIs until the home is ready. But many builders ran out of money, stopped paying EMIs and delayed projects, and the bank came after you because the loan was in your name. So if a builder ever says no EMI till possession, ask yourself why is he asking you to take the loan?

title: iphone 16 vs 17 - Price Drop
description:
Price skimming is a strategic pricing model where a company launches a new, innovative product at the highest possible price and then systematically lowers it over time.

The primary goal is to maximize revenue by "skimming" the top layer of the market first. This initial high price targets early adopters and loyal fans who have a high willingness to pay for the latest product and are not sensitive to price. This phase creates a sense of exclusivity and helps the company quickly recover its research and development costs.

Once the demand from this initial group is met, the company strategically lowers the price in stages. Each price drop appeals to a new, more price-sensitive segment of the market, like those who wait for deals or reviews.

This tactic is most effective for products with strong brand equity and a significant competitive advantage, such as new iPhones, gaming consoles, etc. By selling the same product to different customer groups at different times and prices, a company can maximize its total profit far more effectively than with a single launch price.
transcript: Wait, why is Apple selling its 80,000 rupee iPhone 16 for just 56,999? Now, see, when a new model launches, Apple targets only the diehard fans and early adopters because this group will pay any premium to have the latest tech first. But when this hype ends and a new model launches, they reduce the prices of older models to maximize their sales. This is called price skimming and it's done by hundreds of brands.

With supply tightening globally and policy tailwinds at home, silver is fast turning into one of the most rewarding assets this year.

title: Hidden Tax Behind 10 Minute Delivery Apps
transcript: The Ministry of Consumer Affairs got over 3,000 complaints from users of 10-minute delivery apps. Here's what happened. The recent GST rate cuts made most consumer goods cheaper. >> If it is middle class aspiration, if it's farmer, if it is MSME, if it's for the larger good of the economy, all of them are coming down. >> But many users felt these apps weren't passing on the savings. Here's how it works. When you buy a packet of chips from the store for 20 rupees, the GST is already included in that 20 rupees MRP. But on delivery apps along with MRP, you also pay a delivery fee handling fee. That fee being a service attracts an 18% GST, meaning it has two points of taxation. Once on product, another on the service. And since these apps don't show the tax breakup, many users are urging for better transparency.

title: How BCCI built a Cricket Empireü§Ø
transcript: The Indian cricket industry is worth more than $15 billion. And for cricket, BCCI runs the show. Let's look at how BCCI actually makes money. Around 3% of their income comes from the share of media and advertisements revenue that is generated from the Indian men's team stores. Around 4% comes from the revenue generated through rights, ticketing, and other sources in the WPL. Around 7% comes from the grant of media rights for home matches. Since India has the largest viewership for cricket, this is huge. Around 27% comes from the revenue share that ICC shares with the BCCI. The BCCI is a cashrich body, hence they earn around 12% in interest income. And at last, the biggest chunk, 45% of the income comes from the IPL.

title: Why are Indian Roads So BadüíÄ
transcript: Wait, watch this video. The question is why are Indian roads so bad? Contractors often use cheap materials leading to poor quality roads because contracts go to the lowest bidder, not the best one. Many roads are not designed with proper slopes or drainage leading to water logging which weakens road surfaces and causes potholes. Overloaded trucks destroy roads designed for lighter vehicles causing rapid wear and tear. But the biggest issue is that there's no single road authority. In Delhi alone, four different agencies manage roads and overlapping responsibilities cause poor maintenance and inefficiency.

title: Dark Reality of BIG BRANDS (Planned Obsolescence)
description:
Your phone slows down after a year. Your washing machine breaks right after the warranty ends. Repairing stuff is so expensive, you might as well buy a new one. Sounds familiar? That‚Äôs not by accident - it‚Äôs called planned obsolescence.

In this video, we‚Äôll show you how big brands purposely make their products weaker, harder to fix, or just plain outdated - so you keep buying again and again. Whether it's phones, laptops, or even light bulbs, companies have clever ways to make sure you never stop spending.

This trick costs you more money, creates more waste, and gives you less value. And the worst part? Most people don‚Äôt even know it‚Äôs happening.

Watch till the end to see how you're being fooled - and what you can do about it.

Key sources to dig deeper

Planned Obsolescence  an overview‚Äù on ScienceDirect: explains the business strategy of designing products to become obsolete or useless within a set time.
https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/computer-science/planned-obsolescence?utm

Built To Fail: 7 Examples Of Planned Obsolescence‚Äù (Durability Matters): breaks down 4 major tactics (contrived durability, software updates, perceived obsolescence, prevention of repair) and real‚Äëworld examples.
https://durabilitymatters.com/planned-obsolescence/?utm

Planned Obsolescence - dark truth of the smartphone industry‚Äù (UX‚ÄØPlanet): a focused piece on how smartphones are part of this cycle (software slows down older phones, repairs blocked, etc.).
https://uxplanet.org/planned-obsolescence-dark-truth-of-the-smartphone-industry-c9131c5ff7c4?utm
transcript: Companies are making products worse on purpose. The Feebas Cartel asked, "How do we make more money?" Their answer: Make bulbs burn out faster. Just 1,000 hours. If a company made a longerlasting bulb, they were fined. And it's not just bulbs. Smartphones. Once you could replace the battery. Now you're forced to buy a new one. Cosmetics. 1,200 face washes. Do we really need that many? Or is it just a sales trick? Phone, cameras. Why not one with all the features? Instead, they sell you different models. Even Tesla, buy the car, but subscribe for self-driving. Companies are shifting to recurring income, making you pay forever.

title: How UPI really makes money!?ü§ë
transcript: Phone Pay is heading for a $15 billion IPO. But if UPI apps charge you zero for your payments, how do they actually make money? UPI apps earn their revenue through five major source. One, every time you pay an electricity bill or recharge your phone, the UPI app gets a cut. Two, these voice boxes get UPI providers a subscription fees. Three, your spending data helps these apps sell you loans for which the bank pays a sourcing fee. Four, while banktobank UPI is free, transactions from prepaid wallets over 2,000 rupees charge a fee of 1.1%. Five, when you pay through your UPI lineed credit card, they earn a transaction fee just like your card machines.

title: Why India Can‚Äôt Escape Traffic üò©
transcript: Wait, making wider roads will actually increase our traffic problem. When a new wider road opens for the first few days, the traffic reduces. But after some time, people who were avoiding that route start using it because it's faster. And people who were taking the bus or metro think the road is clear now, I'll just take my car. This eventually creates more traffic. Economists call this phenomenon induced demand. And the best way to solve this problem is to create efficient public transportation.

title: What if India had 0 Tax?‚ö°Ô∏è
transcript: What if there was no income tax in India? Indians would initially have more disposable income. But where would the Indian government get money for roads, defense, healthcare, and education? Government would have to hike other taxes massively. Think GST soaring or corporate taxes going through the roof. This could make everything more expensive. Some countries manage with low or no income tax, often relying on natural resources or very high consumption taxes. For example, UAE charges 0% income tax to its citizens. This is possible because the UAE is heavily funded by oil and gas revenue. So, while no income tax sounds great, the reality is complex. The Indian government will have to find alternative sources for the revenue foregone from personal taxes.

title: Is SILVER the NEW GOLD? ü§î
description:
We have more about currency effect for you below: 

Gold: In USD, gold has returned an average of 7.6% per year over the past three decades. But if you also consider the dollar‚Äôs depreciation, the return for investors in countries like India is closer to 11%. So, while gold has gone up in price, the weaker dollar has made it even more valuable in local currencies.

Silver: Silver has returned 6.4% annually in USD. But after considering currency depreciation, the return jumps to 9.8%.

What this means is that, for investors in countries with weaker currencies, the returns on gold and silver have been better than what the USD numbers show. The combination of rising metal prices and a depreciating dollar has made these investments more attractive in some regions.

Check out the following links for more details: 

1. https://in.investing.com/currencies/usd-inr-historical-data
2. https://www.fundsindia.com/blog/mf-research/silver-lining-is-it-time-to-add-silver-to-your-portfolio/32139
transcript: Gold in the last 30 years has given a 7.6% return in USD. But if I include this effect then the return is not 7.6 it's 11%. Same thing for silver last 30 years dollar return is 6.4%. We have attached the our sources below!

Do show your love in the comments below :)
transcript: Kenya and Nigeria are safer than India. How? In 1990, Indian roads were already 40% deadlier than developed nations like Sweden, UK, and Netherlands. By 2021, this number exploded to 600%. And no, it's not because India is still developing. The Global Road Safety Report 2023 shows income has nothing to do with road deaths. Road deaths aren't only accidents. They can also be failures of accountability.

title: China Slowed Down Earth's Rotation
description:
Did China Really Slow Down Earth's Rotation? 
Sounds crazy - but it‚Äôs true. In this video, we break down how China‚Äôs massive Three Gorges Dam may have actually affected the Earth‚Äôs rotation.

From shifting mass to scientific facts confirmed by NASA, this is one of the wildest ways human activity has impacted the planet - and most people have no idea.

üëâ What caused it?
üëâ How much did Earth slow down?
üëâ Should we be worried?

#China #EarthRotation #ThreeGorgesDam #NASA #GeoEngineering #Zero1 #MindBlown
transcript: China slowed down the earth's rotation. The three gorgeous dam built on the Yangzi river is the biggest dam in the world. It's 600 ft tall and 7,600 ft long and behind it 39 lakh cr L of water. That's enough to supply the entire Delhi for 2 years and 3 months. But why did this slow the earth down? It's due to a physics concept called moment of inertia. When a person spreads his arms, he spins slower because his weight moves away from his core. China did the same to the Earth by lifting trillions of liters of water upward. They pushed the planet's mass away from its core and that slowed Earth's rotation by 0.06 06 microsconds.

title: Price of McDonald's Burgers Across The World
transcript: Take a look at this map. The Big Mac Burger costs 228 rupees in India, 252 in Japan, and a whopping 463 rupees in America. But why? It's because of the purchasing power par which tells us how many goods and services you can buy for the same amount of money in different countries. But since the original method to calculate the PPP is quite complicated, in 1986, The Economist magazine created the Big Mac Index, a simple way to calculate the PPP. Since McDonald's is available in almost all big countries, it acts as a good benchmark for estimating different countries purchasing power. And from this map, we can clearly see that India is much cheaper than the US, UK, and Australia. But to know its flaws, check the pinned comment.

title: Why does India keep its gold abroad?
transcript: in 2024 RBI brought back 100 lakh kilos of gold from Europe but it still holds 400 lakh kilos in the United Kingdom but why does India even keep its gold abroad in 1990 during the foreign exchange crisis India pledged some of its gold reserves to the bank of England to secure a $45 million loan even though India repaid the loan by 1991 RBI decided to keep the gold in London because bringing physical gold back to India and selling it could be a logistical Nightmare and because London has a really liquid gold market it made sense to keep gold there because it gave RBI an option to sell gold whenever India needed cash but today RBI has brought back some of its gold because at times of geopolitical tensions the countries May seize our gold reserves so do you think RBI should bring back all of the gold to India check out the full story at fin shots and follow this

title: Did a 1997 merger ruin Boeing?
description:
In today's episode, we go back over two decades to how a mega-merger might have been the downfall of Boeing. 

For complete information, click here: https://finshots.in/archive/did-a-1997-merger-ruin-boeing/
transcript: this panel at the rear of the aircraft blew midair as the plane reached 16,000 ft and this was a series of accidents by the infamous Boeing 737 Max but how did they get here in 1997 they decided to buy another plane manufacturer McDonald duglas before the merger the ones who actually made these flying machines call the shots but after the merger the management suddenly decided they were too cool to be in the same room as the engineers but no one really noticed anything was wrong not until American Airlines approached its competitor Airbus for the new fuel efficient a32 Neo rather than spending 20 billion on designing a new aircraft Boeing decided to Simply make adjustments to its iconic 737 the result the 737 Max soon everyone knew that it was the billion dollar merger with McDonald Douglas that ultimately became Boeing's downfall check out the full story at finsh shots and follow this channel for more

title: How much debt is TOO MUCH debt? Let‚Äôs find out
description:
Is your debt more than what's safe?
Well, keeping debt under 33% of your income is wise, yet it's not just about percentages. Say you're saving up for a big goal like a home, high debt could slow you down, making even a 'safe' ratio tricky. Thus, an apt debt to income ratio for a person depends on several factors and vary from person to person.
Want the full picture on managing your debt wisely?
Watch our detailed video!

title: How does Japan bounce back every time despite experiencing more than 1500 earthquakes every year?
transcript: Japan experiences 1,500 earthquakes every year here are three reasons how Japan's quake-prone economy bounces back every time number one robust economic policies when Japan was hit by a crisis nearly 13 years ago its former prime minister late Shinzo Abbe renewed the fiscal policy monetary policy and made structural reforms and got them to achieve just one thing growth number two investments in disaster management since the 1980s its government has bed in about $6.4 billion on average every year in disaster prevention measures number three businesses here aren't just survivors beautiful example of this is icha a small moochi shop founded by a Japanese family in the year 1,000 even today it serves toasted Mochi in short it prioritize long-term sustainability over short-term profits this ensured Japan bounce back quickly from its impact check out the full story at fin shots and follow this channel for more

title: DARK days of Indian Economy (1991)
description:
In 1991, India faced a severe economic crisis, with foreign exchange reserves dwindling to just $1.2 billion - barely enough to cover three weeks of imports. To avert a default, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) pledged 67 tonnes of gold as collateral for emergency loans. This included airlifting 47 tonnes to the Bank of England and 20 tonnes to the Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS). 

This drastic measure led to significant economic reforms, including the devaluation of the rupee, trade policy changes, and the initiation of liberalization under Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao and Finance Minister Dr. Manmohan Singh. By November 1991, the gold was repurchased, and the country's economic trajectory shifted toward growth and modernization. In 2024, India repatriated nearly 100 tonnes of gold from the UK, marking a full circle in its economic journey. 

For more details, check the sources given below: 

1. https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/mcminis/how-gold-is-intertwined-with-indias-economic-growth-9622741.html?utm
2. https://deepakgouda.github.io/blog/2020/economic_liberalisation/?utm
3. https://ddnews.gov.in/en/india-brings-gold-back-to-domestic-vaults-first-time-since-1991/?utm
transcript: 1991 we barely had enough to cover two weeks of imports we pledged tons and tons of gold to the bank of england and the union bank of switzerland this was actually flown in and this footage is actually real if you look at the economy we have not looked back the economy has actually done well so gold really helped us

title: India's BIGGEST Trading Scam of 2025‚ö°Ô∏è
transcript: If you've lost money in Bank Nifty during January 2023 and March 2025, you may have been set up. Sebi just exposed a US firm called Jane Street. They made over 4,800 cr rupees in India by allegedly manipulating the market and it affected many retail traders. Here's what they did. They pumped in huge amounts of cash to buy stocks which are part of the Bank Nifty index. This caused the index to cause small and timed movements around expiry. But behind the scenes, Jane Street was placing bearish bets that the market would fall. And just before expiry, they sold everything in the cash market. The index dropped fast. Retail traders lost money while Jane Street made huge profits from those bearish bets. SBI says this wasn't a one-time event. It happened again and again. Now, Jane Street is banned and their assets are frozen.

title: GOLD v/s SILVER - Who will give MORE RETURNS? ü§î
description:
Gold vs Silver: which is better in 2025? 

If you had put ‚Çπ1 lakh into silver back in 2005, today it would be worth around ‚Çπ9 lakhs. But the same money in gold would‚Äôve grown to almost ‚Çπ15 lakhs. And when you look at the last 50 years, silver has actually underperformed gold nearly 80% of the time.

The main reason is how the two metals are used. Gold is mostly seen as a safe store of value, something people turn to during inflation or crises. Silver, on the other hand, has a big role in industries - like solar panels, electronics, EVs, even medical devices. That means silver‚Äôs price moves up and down much more with economic cycles, making it more unpredictable.

In short, gold usually offers steadiness, while silver comes with higher swings‚Äîsometimes rewarding, sometimes risky. 

üìñ Source: 

1. Funds India: https://www.fundsindia.com/blog/mf-research/silver-lining-is-it-time-to-add-silver-to-your-portfolio/32139

2. World Silver Survey: https://silverinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/World_Silver_Survey-2025.pdf

3. World Gold Council: https://www.gold.org/goldhub/data/gold-demand-by-country
transcript: Gold or silver, which has been the smarter bet? 1 lak rupees in silver in 2005 would be worth about 9 lak rupees today. But the same amount in gold would worth nearly 15 lak rupees. In fact, over the last 50 years, silver has underperformed gold almost 80% of the time. So what will you choose? Gold or silver.

title: Budget 2026 Explained! ü§Ø
Why FDs Remain India‚Äôs Most Trusted Investment ü§Ø
description:
If you liked this short, we‚Äôve discussed FDs and other investment options in detail in our episode on short-term investing: https://youtu.be/khPuekcMOJo?si=NA-PpCL_VZrug-65

Many people believe that Fixed Deposits never beat inflation. But that‚Äôs not always true. Looking at the numbers from 2013 to 2024, a clear story emerges: FD rates and inflation rates show that out of 12 years, FDs delivered positive real returns in 9 years. Only in 2013, 2020, and 2021 did the returns slip into negative territory.

So, what does this mean for you? Simply put, the real return is the FD rate minus inflation. For example, if your FD earns 7% but inflation is 5%, your money actually grows by 2% in real terms.

You can check the sources here to learn more about FDs and inflation:

1. Check savings rate scheme information by National Savings Institute: https://www.nsiindia.gov.in/(S(l0l1eufjq0rcfee3wm2urk55))/InternalPage.aspx?Id_Pk=185

2. India's inflation rate over years: 
https://www.macrotrends.net/global-metrics/countries/ind/india/inflation-rate-cpi
transcript: Fixed deposits do not beat inflation. Not true. You just have to know this table over here. In 2013, we have all the way to 2024, we have fixed deposit rates and we have inflation rates. title: 90% of Ambulances Are USELESS in India üöë
description:
India faces a serious challenge when it comes to emergency care. The global standard ambulance response time is 10 minutes, but in India about 60% arrive late. 

Even when they do arrive, many are not equipped for emergencies - 90% lack oxygen or proper equipment, and a large number are run by untrained personnel. According to an AIIMS report, this often leads to patients not making it to the hospital in time. Improving ambulance services is key to saving lives after accidents.

Check out the report by AIIMS & NITI Aayog: https://www.niti.gov.in/sites/default/files/2023-02/AIIMS_STUDY_2_0.pdf
transcript: Imagine surviving the accident but dying in the ambulance. The global standard response time for an ambulance is 10 minutes. In India, 60% of ambulances arrive late. Only 55% of accident victims reach the hospital within the golden hour, the first hour when survival chances are the highest. And even when ambulances do arrive on time, 90% of them don't have oxygen or proper equipment.

title: Don‚Äôt fall for this scam!
transcript: Imagine you get a call from a familiar voice and he's asking you to urgently transfer a large sum of money for the hospital bill. Well, it's the new face of cyber crime and it works because it taps into the urgency. We don't even question once. We are wired to obey familiar voices. AI doesn't need hours of audio to fake your voice. Just 30 seconds from a call recordings is enough. But it's not just voice. Scammers are staging fake Zoom calls, sending cops to virtually arrest victims. It's called digital arrest, and it's terrifyingly effective. It feels so real that even people at the top are being scammed. As per this RBI report in 2023, almost 4,400 cyber attacks were attacked daily and has been increasing since. So, next time you get a call, pause, confirm, think twice, use a safe word in an emergency.

title: Dark REALITY of Indian's Road accidents
description:
#roadsafety #shorts #accident 

Indian roads are among the deadliest in the world and the data doesn‚Äôt even tell the full story. Nearly 1.7 lakh people died in road accidents in 2022, but according to WHO and independent studies, India may be underreporting deaths by up to 40%.

And that's a serious problem: when a crash happens, the first step is filing an FIR. In more than 80% of cases, the cause is recorded as ‚Äúhuman error‚Äù. Bad road design, faulty vehicles, or poor infrastructure rarely make it to the report. By the time this data reaches the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB), the real causes vanish.

This is why the Indian Status Report on Road Safety 2024 calls for better data and crash surveillance systems. Countries like Sweden, the US, and Australia have already implemented such systems and seen dramatic improvements in road safety. Meanwhile, India even received $500 million from the World Bank and ADB to improve its road safety framework - but progress has been slow.

üìë Please find all source links of all the information we mention in this short: 

1. https://morth.nic.in/sites/default/files/Road-Accident-in-India-2023-Publications.pdf
2. https://tripc.iitd.ac.in/assets/publication/India_Status_Report_on_Road_Safety-20242.pdf
3. https://tripc.iitd.ac.in/assets/publication/RSI_2023_web.pdf
4. https://documents1.worldbank.org/curated/en/882411655916854017/pdf/India-State-Support-Program-Road-Safety-Program-for-Results-Project.pdf?utm_source=chatgpt.com
transcript: 80% of road crashes in India are blamed on the wrong cause. When a crash happens in India, the first step is filing an FIR. And in over 80% of cases, the cause is written down as human error. Bad road design or faulty vehicles are rarely reported. By the time it reaches the NCB report, the real causes are gone. And WHO says India may be under reportporting road deaths by up to 40%. India took $500 million to improve road safety. [Music]

title: What's REALLY Behind Road Accidents??
transcript: 1.75 lakh lives have been lost due to road accidents. That's 20 people every 60 minutes. When there's a road accident, 75% of those people involved in the accidents have a license. This study in Delhi followed 800 people who have a valid driving license. The report found that three out of 10 people actually took the test and the rest seven didn't take the test. And you know what? They even did a surprise test from some of these people to figure out whether they understand the road signs.

title: The Secret Behind Mutual Fund Investing! üìà
transcript: Good batsman isn't judged by one century. It's about consistent performance. Well, mutual funds are not any different. What really matters are rolling returns. For example, you're trying to compare the mutual funds 3-year returns over a 10-year period. Instead of just looking at returns from 2015 to 2017 or 2017 to 2019, you would calculate the 3-year return across every possible period, not just one. That means for every single day, week or month starting in 2015 and ending in 2025. If the fund consistently delivers strong three-year rolling returns across most time periods, it's a sign of stable and reliable performance even across volatile markets. That's like a batsman scoring runs in all conditions, all formats. The Varat Kohli of mutual funds.
